name: Improper Handling of Insufficient Entropy in TRNG
description: True random number generators (TRNG) generally have a limited source of entropy and therefore can fail or block.
extended_description: The rate at which true random numbers can be generated is limited. It is important that one uses them only when they are needed for security.

note: REALIZATION: This weakness is caused during implementation of an architectural security tactic.

common_consequences.note: A program may crash or block if it runs out of random numbers.

description: Rather than failing on a lack of random numbers, it is often preferable to wait for more numbers to be created.

demonstrative_examples.text:
<Intro_Text>This code uses a TRNG to generate a unique session id for new connections to a server:</Intro_Text>
               <Example_Code Nature="Bad" Language="C">
                  <xhtml:div>while (1){<xhtml:div style="margin-left:1em;">
                        <xhtml:div>if (haveNewConnection()){<xhtml:div style="margin-left:1em;">if (hwRandom()){<xhtml:div style="margin-left:1em;">int sessionID = hwRandom();<xhtml:br/>createNewConnection(sessionID);</xhtml:div>} } }</xhtml:div>
                        </xhtml:div>
                     </xhtml:div>
                  </xhtml:div>
               </Example_Code>
               <Body_Text>This code does not attempt to limit the number of new connections or make sure the TRNG can successfully generate a new random number. An attacker may be able to create many new connections and exhaust the entropy of the TRNG. The TRNG may then block and cause the program to crash or hang.</Body_Text>

notes.text:
As of CWE 4.5, terminology related to randomness, entropy, and
	   predictability can vary widely. Within the developer and other
	   communities, "randomness" is used heavily. However, within
	   cryptography, "entropy" is distinct, typically implied as a
	   measurement. There are no commonly-used definitions, even within
	   standards documents and cryptography papers. Future versions of
	   CWE will attempt to define these terms and, if necessary,
	   distinguish between them in ways that are appropriate for
	   different communities but do not reduce the usability of CWE for
	   mapping, understanding, or other scenarios.
